title: Japanese PM backs idea of EU superstate as he takes swipe at Brexit on visit to Brussels
text:
Japanese PM backs idea of EU superstate as he takes swipe at Brexit on visit to Brussels Japanese PM backs idea of EU superstate as he takes swipe at Brexit on visit to Brussels JAPANESE prime minister Shinzo Abe today gave his full-throated support to the idea of a European superstate as he made repeated digs at Brexit following a meeting with top eurocrats in Brussels. PUBLISHED: 13:20, Tue, Mar 21, 2017 | UPDATED: 14:05, Tue, Mar 21, 2017 
The Tokyo premier said he wanted to see Brussels “forge through with integration” despite Britain’s decision to leave as he gave a vocal thumbs up to the EU project. 
In a series of closely choreographed remarks he heaped lavish praise on the bloc and claimed it was bringing “various challenges under control” including migration, populism and terror. 
He made his remarks as eurocrats look to speed up the signing of a trade deal with Japan in light of Brexit and Theresa May’s plan to pursue a global agenda for an independent Britain. Related articles Britain braced for MASSIVE Brexit divorce demand from EU bosses 
Mr Abe’s support for European integration was an unusually forceful intervention into European domestic politics by a world leader and comes at a particularly troubling time for the bloc. 
Although Brussels safely navigated the minefield of the recent Dutch elections, seeing off the challenge of Geert Wilders, eurosceptic parties nonetheless grew their support. 
And Marine Le Pen is expected to perform well in the upcoming French presidential battle even if she looks set to eventually lose out to the pro-EU centrist Emmanuel Macron. GETTY Japanese premier Shinzo Abe was in town for an incredibly choreographed display of unity GETTY Mr Abe heaped praise on the EU during a meticulously orchestrated press conference 
On top of that, France was rocked by yet another terror scare this month with the incident at Orly Airport, the latest in a long line of incidents that have raised questions over Europe’s security. 
And Turkey continues to threaten to pull the plug on its refugee deal with the EU which is keeping a lid on migration amid growing tensions between Ankara and Brussels. 
Speaking at a press conference in the EU Council’s brand new Europa building, Mr Abe said: “As the international community today faces many challenges including terrorism, refugees and attempts to change the status quo unilaterally by force. 
“Japan and the international community need more than ever a strong, united Europe. Against this backdrop I am greatly encouraged to see the EU bringing various challenges under control and as a global player continuing to show a strong will to contribute to the maintenance and strengthening of the international order. 
“Japan supports a strong Europe and a strong Europe will be good and conducive for the world, Japan and Europe. Japan would like to support the EU to forge through with the integration going forward.” Japan would like to support the EU to forge through with the integration going forward Japanese PM Shinzo Abe 
He added: “Countries of Europe, as well as Japan, have achieved prosperity amidst the international order founded on the rule of law. Going forward Japan, the EU and the US should hand in hand work to maintain and reinforce the free and open international order.” 
The Japanese premier’s omission of the UK from his list of global players seemed like a pointed snub over Brexit, which he then reinforced by saying he did not want to see Britain’s decision to leave negatively impact on the rest of the EU. 
He said: “As for the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, of which the negotiation will be started soon, ensuring transparency and productivity as well as providing for a transition period will be important for all the relevant parties. 
“I hope that the EU and the UK will continue your close partnership as the Brexit process moves forward. I expect with confidence that the debate concerning the future of the EU after Brexit will definitely aim toward conserving the cohesion of Europe as a whole, including on the security front.” The best pictures from EU Summit 2017 Fri, March 10, 2017 EU leaders will gather for a two-day summit to discuss a number of issues including Great Britain's exit from the Union
